item.title: The Call Of Duty: Black Ops 7 Skin Situation Keeps Getting More Confusing
item.content:encoded:
Good morning! Itâ€™s cooling down where I live, which makes me so damn happy. Anyway, welcome to Morning Checkpoint, Kotakuâ€˜s daily round-up of news and other stuff you might care about. Today, we got a big update for a classic indie game, a way to get Borderlands 4 for free, a hidden mode in Silksong, and Treyarch making more changes to what will and wonâ€™t transfer into next yearâ€™s Call of Duty. 

Treyarch Changes Its Plans With (Some) Black Ops 6 Skins Again

The Call of Duty wacky cosmetics saga continues. Last month, following a large online backlash against ugly crossover skins and serious competition from Battlefield 6â€˜s popular and grounded beta, Activision and Treyarch announced that BLOPS6â€²s skins wonâ€™t carry over into Black Ops 7. The idea was to give the upcoming sequel a fresh start and not have people running around as Stan Smith from American Dad on day one. A lot of people liked this change, but not everyone was happy that the skins theyâ€™d worked hard for would not be moving forward. So uh, Treyarch is making some more changes.

That's not all! The Guild Override camo is joining the Zombies Main Quest Reward & "New Orders" Operator skins, and will be available at the launch of Black Ops 7 for those who digitally Pre-Order ðŸ”¥ pic.twitter.com/Jz3GoZZyTq

â€” Call of Duty (@CallofDuty) September 10, 2025

On September 10, Treyarch announced on social media that some zombie-related skins would now carry over into Black Ops 7. Specifically, the Operator Skin rewards earned by completing main quests and the New Orders Prestige Level 1000 cosmetic items. So no, it doesnâ€™t seem like all the wacky crossover skins from last year will be showing up in Black Ops 7, but who knows? Treyarch and Activision are changing things up so fast right now that in a few weeks, this might all be out the window. Itâ€™s almost like Activision is a bit nervous about how much of a bite Battlefield 6 might take out of it this holiday season.

Drink Enough Beers, And You Might Get A Free Copy Of Borderlands 4

Do you like drinking beer? Do you like Borderlands 4? Do you like free video games? Are you tired of answering my questions? Well, Iâ€™ll stop and explain that Gearbox, 2K, and beer maker Voodoo Ranger have teamed up for a new promotion. As spotted by GameSpot, a bunch of specifically branded Voodoo Ranger beers will contain various Borderlands 4 rewards, including 1,000 free copies of Borderlands 4. So to have a decent shot, all you need to do is buy like 200 beers, and that probably isnâ€™t very expensive, right? I donâ€™t drink booze, so let me do a quick search online andâ€¦oh my god!

Thereâ€™s A Hidden, Much Harder Mode In Silksong

Since the moment it was released earlier this month, popular 2D action platformer Hollow Knight: Silksong has been at the center of quite the discourse around video game difficulty. Some people say itâ€™s too hard, others say itâ€™s not too bad, and still others are just skipping all of this and modding the game to make it easier. Well, donâ€™t worry, thereâ€™s a secret difficulty option hidden in the game behind the Konami cheat code. But this newly discovered secret mode actually makes Silksong much, much harder as you can only die once. Good luck with that!

The 14-Year-Old Binding Of Issac Just Got A Massive Update

Yeah, sure, the creator behind 2011â€™s roguelike classic The Binding of Issac recently announced the release date for his long-awaited next game, but that doesnâ€™t mean he canâ€™t keep working on his OG hit. item.title: 9 Things You Need To Know Before Starting Elden Ring Nightreignâ€˜s New Hard Mode
item.content:encoded:
Elden Ring Nightreignâ€˜s new hard mode, Deep of Night, is about to go live, and publisher Bandai Namco has released a new explainer on YouTube helping to onboard fans to the multiplayer rogueliteâ€™s most challenging content yet. Combined with reams of datamined clues over the past month, we have a pretty good idea of what to expect heading into it. FromSoftware will no doubt have a few surprise curveballs hiding up its sleeve, but the announced changes alone should be enough to make even veteran Nightfarers feel like naÃ¯ve grist for the Soulslike mill all over again.

When does Deep of Night go live?

In keeping with all past updates, Nightreignâ€˜s new mode is set to be available in the game starting around 9:00 p.m. ET on September 10 across PlayStation 5, PS4, Xbox Series X/S, Xbox One, and PC.

Nightlords and shifting Earth events will be completely random

In Deep of Night, players wont get to pick which bosses they face ahead of time, or choose which Shifting Earth events are active. Relic choices and builds will all have to be adapted to on the fly. Youâ€™ll want to have multiple relic presets ready so you can choose after seeing what Nightlord youâ€™re facing before the match loads.

Enemies hit way harder

A clip from the Deep of Night trailer shows trash mobs taking several more hits to fall at the start of a run. According to datamines, most enemies in the first depth will have around double their normal health and power, with stats only ramping up from there.

Items come with more buffs and debuffs

Players will have to be a lot more careful about what they pick up when theyâ€™re running around Limveld. While gear comes with extra buff slots, it also comes with a debuff that will make it easier to die. Examples shown include status ailment buildup upon getting hit and taking more damage from the Nightâ€™s Tide.

New red mutated enemies are extra tough but drop new rare gear

These variants will be even stronger, potentially stopping a run dead in its tracks. Hoping to swoop through a mine for a quick crafting stone? Thought you could demolish that Cathedral golem all by yourself? Not this time! But with the greater risk comes greater rewards. It seems like these red enemies will also drop red gear with new powers that will probably end up making or breaking runs.

Additional Deep Relic slots expand buildcrafting

Players will have access to three additional relic slots that can only be filled with relics earned from Deep of Night. Thatâ€™s because these will each come with negative stats as well as positive ones. According to datamines, examples include ones that completely invert characterâ€™s usual stat progressions. Fighters can become spell casters, squishy glass cannons can become tanks. It looks like Deep of Night will completely turn the established build metas on their heads.

Sometimes the map will be completely empty

There are at least two randomly occurring events we currently know about in Deep of Night. The first will hide the Nightlord icon for the entire run so you have no idea who youâ€™re facing at the end. The other will erase every icon from the map so you have no idea what camps are where. Players will just have to wing it or rely on their memorization of the probabilities from the hundreds of randomized seeds a run can pull from.

Completing runs earns rank points to unlock challenging depths

This scoring system will double as a skill-based matchmaking system for grouping you with other Deep of Night players. Once you progress out of Depth 1 you can never go back, but every Depth after that can see you pushed back to an earlier one if you keep failing.

Everdark Sovereign bosses can appear

Thatâ€™s right, ED Libra and the gang could be what greets you at the end of an already harrowing run. Good thing youâ€™ve spent months practicing each of those variants, right? Right??

The Bell Bearing Hunter just got scarier

The gameâ€™s hardest field boss can also be one of its red variants. Have fun! Iâ€™m sure wasting five minutes trying to kill him will be totally worth it. If you want to find out more about what to expect out of Deep of Night before embarking on your own run, YouTuber Scavinjx has a great breakdown of many of the new relic effects, passives, and exact damage and health multipliers based on recent datamined info.
